rComments: He was VERY thorough with the theories, especially the math & the proofs which was nice. If you arent up to par with calculus and differentials then skip this course because it's all calculus. He was so nice during office hours, his tests were hard but fair & grading was generous, and his lectures were very organized & clear. He's great!

I don't know how he is in CHM135 because I didn't take it, but he was AMAZING in CHM222. Made me wanna learn more thermodynamics and take upper-year courses taught by him. Such a sweet guy who cares about his students & teaching in general. Highly recommend if you're willing to put in the work because thermodynamics is actually really hard
teacherRatingTags: ["Skip class? You won't pass.", 'Accessible outside class']

rComments: He cares about his students, tests are descent, but his lecturing skills are horrible. Every time after I come out of his lectures, I end up finding thermodynamics harder to understand. I nominate him for Best Overcomplication Professor U of T award

He cares about his students, tests are descent, but his lecturing skills are horrible. Every time after I come out of his lectures, I end up finding thermodynamics harder to understand. I had to rely on my textbook to reclarify concepts he makes more complicated. You are better off reading the textbook only than attending his lectures.

Lectures did include all material on the test, however it also included irrelevant material. I ended up leaving lectures more confused than going in. Reading the textbook thoroughly is a good idea for Professor Schofield's section.

Professor Schofield taught the third section of CHM135 that focused on thermodynamics and electrochemistry. His lecture notes were fairly comprehensive, and they included details that were beyond the scope of this course to improve our understanding. He works out the examples provided, and he emphasizes a more conceptual understanding.
Average prof, easy material. You still need to study the lecture slides a little bit more in depth.

Tests are irrelevant to the content focused on in class. It honestly doesn't matter how well you prepare there isn't enough time given to provide proper answers during tests.  Final was terrible. Major curve needed because of this.

I got the mark I did because of a bell curve - not because of my actual performance on tests. I left each exam feeling dejected and frustrated after pouring so much time into this course to be tested on content that felt irrelevant to what we learned in class. There are not enough examples or chances to practice questions the way the prof tests.

If the average is consistently low (to the point of curving the whole class up 22%), then there is something wrong with the teacher, not the students. This is not a case of students being lazy. If the entire class is doing poorly (save a few at the top who happen to learn this way), then the prof should adjust his methods. Frustrating course.

Although he curves the grades to help make up for his poorly-written tests, this is an unfair method because it favours students who happen to be good at getting part marks on questions that they do not understand at all. Instead of testing actual ability, he tests the ability to spew fragments of correct answers without understanding.

Do not be discouraged by the negative posts.  Schofield emphasizes the theoretical approach to introductory physical chemistry rather than just plugging in numbers to an equation.  Be familiar with your differentials and integrals.    Those that did not do well simply did not study the material the way they should have.  Schofield is a great prof

He's just one of those regular profs at UofT. Not good, but not bad either. Honestly, if you're complaining that his tests are hard, you need to take a hard look at yourself and your studying methods instead of downvoting this guy like crazy. 220's your typical UofT course. Average prof, lazy and whiny students.
teacherRatingTags: ['Get ready to read', "Skip class? You won't pass."]

rComments: prob got a 20 on the final even thought I aced both term tests, very irrelevant final

Brutal prof. Does not explain concepts well. Tries to cram more than can be covered effectively. Does not provide many examples or opportunities to practice realistic test/exam material. Asks questions completely different from what was taught. He knows students will do poorly and require a mark adjustment but makes tests unbelievably hard anyways.

Professor Schofield is extremely unfair. He makes everything super challenging. Tests us on concepts he spent 5 minutes talking about and ignores the other 99% of the concepts we repeatedly learned and expanded on. The questions he gives are nothing like any assigned questions or previous year test that he posts. Has to bell curve bc every1 fails
Exams are not reflective of material taught in lecture and tutorial. Frustrating.

While it is not his fault that the content of this course is difficult, it IS his fault that he tests and teaches in such a way that makes it more difficult than it needs to be. He also frequently goes over his allotted lecture time, making students choose between missing part of this class and their class immediately after, which is ridiculous.

He's generally been one of the fairest profs I believe, gives you everything you need to slove problems, and the equation sheet is amazing. Although the second test was hard, there was a very large adjustment (22%) to account for the difficulty which I though was very very fair. A bit dry in terms of a presenter, but it was okay.
He makes everything far more confusing than it needs to be.

He doesn't post any solutions to the problems he assigns for tutorials, so if you don't get to them in class, you will never know if you are doing something write or wrong. Sometimes even the TAs don't understand his questions.

This professor makes fairly difficult material even MORE difficult by lacking organization and clarity in his lectures. His tests are often unreflective of the material taught in class, with sinister twists to what should be familiar material.
HORRIBLE CLASS !! DROP IT! Tests are impossible and it's all chemical proofs.
Awesome!!
Test is complete irrelevant to the problem set and past tests. Unacceptable.

This professor ought to be congratulated on teaching a course this poorly conceived!  It takes a certain amount of courage to spend a whole semester teaching one thing then test on something completely different! In addition to sleight of hand this prof excels at obscuring  information such as answers to problem sets and what he is talking about!
This is the absolute worst course I have ever taken in my entire life.
if you take this course good luck, the content itself is ok its just this prof brings it to a whole new level of bull that you will never need in med or pharm school
teacherRatingTags: ['Tough grader', "Skip class? You won't pass.", 'Lecture heavy']

rComments: Tests do not reflect lecture material/problem sets given
Material taught and given for practice do not reflect the tests AT ALL
Meh. Would retake class for a different reason.
Tests don't reflect material very well
Terrible Lectures Few explanations giving Spends all class deriving equations that we may or may not need to know No enthusiasm CHM220 is the worst class I have ever taken.

Such an incredibly confusing teacher. The lecture styles are difficult to follow and he doesn't make the material clear at all. The textbook for the course explained much more clearly but did not provide the same style of material as Schofield. Terribly difficult tests. So bad. He's funny though.

The prof was good. The problem with this class was organization. I felt like the tutorial material and practice tests were unreflective of our own assessments. The assessments themselves were out of very little (25) so it was really tough to score high. The first test is deceptively straightforward, it gets a lot harder. Good prof,bad class.

How is this guy even a professor? This is an awful class, worst experience of university. He should be assessed on his lecturing, especially when 100 students drop after the first class. If you have him as a prof, don't even bother taking this class until someone else teaches it. I needed this for pharmacy, so unfortunately I had to suck it up.
he is a good prof, as long as you read the textbook, u can get high marks. His test is fair and easy.
The worst prof I ever had. Makes things complicated, like they're not complicated enough. Also is not nice at office hours.
Hard, but nevertheless one of the best lecturers and scientists that has ever thought me.
i rather jump in front of a subway than take his exam.
OMG. DEATH!
i can't resist sleeping in his classes. incredibly boring. (some people actually snored loudly in his lectures)
No Comments

Schofield is one of those okay profs that could have been better organized with lecture notes and explained things in a better way. But his term test was very fair and if you did all the assigned problems, you'll definitely do well. A nice guy ^_^
got me into chem I'm going into chem engineering from stupid biology.  The exam reversed the laws of physics but it was so hard I got belled to a 100 so I'm not complaining.
Too much history, too much calculus.  Test was fair, exam was instant death!  Schofield himself is a STUD.. ;]
Great attempt at helping students, but his tests are a little tricky.
You tried to help us!
the concepts that he tries to teach are more suited for higher years, but will be a little too confusing for a first year course. he does care for students though, and makes lectures interesting
He's as confusing as the derivatives he puts on his overheads. But he's interesting though.
Engaging and informative. Understanding the derivations is an absolute necessity!
Wonderful Prof.
his lecture notes aren't helpful at all when it comes to those who skip classes.

awesome lecture notes = easy course!
